Martin:  You left out JOBS!  Don't you think jobs for young black men (and other young people) are important?

You miss the author's point and misinterpret just about everything written above. Far from criticizing Malcolm X or the NAACP the author draws a parallel between 2nd Amendment supporters and figures from the Civil Rights Movement.

He points out that they share common ground with regard to civil liberties, and suggests that both groups could benefit from reevaluating traditional views of their constituencies.

The article was decidedly not Left/Right yet you purposefully introduce this bias in your opening sentence. To an reader interested in a worthwhile conversation about seemingly disparate civil rights groups your comment is partisan and unappreciated.
Sure, Ross. Not left/right, but pro-gun.

Where to begin...

I'm glad you support the Huey P. Newton Gun Club, out of some equal rights magnanimity that is uncharacteristic of someone on the right. Using that magnanimity as the vehicle from which to take a swipe at the NAACP, Reverend Sharpton and, Malcolm X, no less, is disingenuous, to be kind.

The problem isn't that blacks can't get as many guns as whites. The problem is that an increasing number of white cops feel perfectly comfortable using their guns on black men, when they should be remembering the oath they pledged and refrain from doing harm onto a fellow citizen.

John Crawford III, Mike Brown, Vonderrit Myers, and all of the other young black men who've died recently were unarmed young men who died at the hand of an armed policemen who used a supposed fear for their lives as justification to shoot to kill. No gun would have saved these young men.

A country that has as many guns as it has citizens is one that has too many guns.

#BlackLivesMatter is about the cessation of police brutality on young black men. It has no bearing on the gun rights of whites or blacks. Using Jim Crow to advance the right to bear arms is the cynical use of a false equivalency in order to make an unrelated point.

So many Americans do not know the basic things about mathematics, writing or our government and forget about science which many look upon as a hinderance. I'm not convinced that "babies having babies" leads directly to lack of employment skills - lack of community support and lack of access to good education play a big part, too - but anyone concerned about unplanned pregnancies should be willing to support wide access to family-planning facilities, contraception and safe, legal early-term abortion. And yet we so often see the opposite.

Our educational system carries a burden not seen elsewhere in the world. It is expected to provide both educational and social services. These demands overload the system.

Many students are destined to fail due to the gross dysfunction of their families. Often, they are born into an intellectual and social desert that does not revere or support education.

While it may be politically incorrect, the truth is that it is impossible for schools to consistently reverse the damage done by rudderless families.

"Babies having babies" has become the accepted norm in many communities, and it has created impoverished dynasties who lack the skills to be employable.

We need to support early childhood education in every way possible for it gives them the best chance that we can offer. But I fear it will not be enough to break the cycle of poverty.

In immigrants, we see the difference that intact families and reverence for education makes. They often succeed where others fail. We must encourage both if we wish to secure a bright future for our country.

"Until the 1970s, we were pre-eminent in mass education," That is a half truth. What turned America into an economic and education powerhouse were two elements; First was the great industrial base that produced victory in World War II.  But, the most important element was the GI Bill.  That fantastic piece of legislation propelled an entire generation of veterans into college and trade schools.  it fulfilled the American dream for men and women who had given their all during the war. It was a promise fulfilled.  The 1970s saw the last of the baby boomers enter college. The boomers benefited from their parents who became doctors, lawyers, accountants, engineers, teachers and more. But by the 1970s America's industrial might was undercut by trade agreements that exported jobs, expertise and entire industries overseas.  That in turn decimated the value of college education. Trade policies destroyed more than jobs.  It destroyed the American middle class and ability to move up the economic ladder.  Once we destroyed the industrial base and jobs the next to fall would be education. We  even question the value of college education.  The parents of baby boomers are aghast at that question as are most baby boomers. But the next generation, the children of boomers, is faced with more obstacles; fewer jobs, fewer well paying jobs and inability to create middle class jobs in industry that once were bountiful.  Why get training or education for non-existent jobs? There is hopelessness.

The question should be framed as to whether Palestinians are willing to abandon their claims to 100% of Israel, in return for Israel abandoning her claim to 5% of the West Bank, or alternatively, compensating Palestinians with "land swaps" for land seized for settlements. As long as Palestinians promulgate a strictly a "one to the exclusion of the other" doctrine, Israel has little, if any, incentive to halt settlement expansion and could conceivably expand settlements to the banks of the Jordan River.

The problem with politically, culturally and geographically bifurcated states (Think Pakistan and Bangladesh!), is that they are inherently unstable and subject to dissolution. There will never likely be a single Palestinian state, but there may be two, with Israel between them, as India lies between Pakistan and Bangladesh. Palestine on the West Bank may eventually obtain a "modus-vivendi" with Israel, while Palestine in Gaza will remain in a perpetual state of war with Israel and suffer the resulting consequences. Read the Hamas Covenant, particularly Articles 7 and 13, at: http://avalon.law.yale.edu/20th_century/hamas.asp

The REAL and relevant question is just how much land do the Israelis need in order to accommodate the new settlers from Eastern Europe and elsewhere? Unemployment among college graduates is 50% higher than it was in 2006.

Yes, unemployment among college graduates is lower than among non-graduates, but this has *always* been true. It does not explain our current high unemployment.

World wide, the problem with the economy is lack of demand - not lack of supply. (Lack of education implies a supply problem).

Blaming lack of education for inequality and economic stagnation distracts from the true causes and cures of these problems.

The citizens of our nation have been cynically misinformed and divided - easy to do, when jobs are scarce, and don't pay enough to survive. Paying poverty wages to the bottom 30% of workers, then giving them EITC and food stamps to survive, provides raw material for cynical politicians to divide the populace, and foment hate and blame for the vaguely defined "others" and "takers". (Better to raise the minimum wage - favored by 70% of voters).

Our nation is becoming ungovernable.

Given the social instability, divisiveness, upheaval, and paralysis of our national government, which can result of failure to fix our economy: Blaming inequality and economic stagnation on the wrong causes - even implicitly - is a dangerous game.

The U.S. experienced high long-term over a period of more than 50 years from the 1860s through the 1920s. Of course, the Great Depression and WWII interrupted that growth as the frothiness of that growth hit a wall due to speculation. But, it returned again in the 1950s and 1960s after WWII. The idea that no nation has had such a long period of high growth is fiction.

China's growth rate does not have to continue at 7% for decades. As long as it grows faster than 4% for long periods (slowly reaching that floor from its current growth rate), it will eventually exceed the U.S. economy in size as the American economy ages and continues to slow down too.

If you had actually looked at the paper you would  have seen that Summers and Pritchett did NOT argue that reversion to the mean was why Chinese growth could not logically be expected to continue ad infinitum. What they actually said was that: "there are substantial reasons that China and India may grow much less rapidly than is currently anticipated. Most importantly, history teaches that abnormally rapid growth is rarely persistent, even though economic forecasts invariably extrapolate recent growth. " Pointing out that previous experience suggests that growth hasn't continued in the past seems unexceptional to me.

'The paper’s authors put it in baseball terms. “If a hitter has a hot streak with a batting average up 50 points over the past 20 at-bats, then we would forecast a return to the average batting average over the next 20 at-bats,”...'

Really? And that is the only argument? If that kind of nonsense passes for an argument in an economics paper, that so-called "science" is even more dismal than I ever imagined. Are they implying that the last 30 years of extremely fast economic growth in China was just a "hot streak" - a period of incredibly good luck with no basis in actual policies and actions? And what do the Soviets have to do with that? There is literally nothing in common between the two countries, their economic, political, geographical and demographic situations. The only common thing, it appears, that they both experienced prolonged periods of fat economic growth. So based on that commonality and because in USSR the growth gave way to stagnation, the conclusion is that the same fate awaits China? And a respected economics professor, ex-president of Harvard no less, seriously argues that point? If there was ever needed any proof that Americal policy elites are just a bunch of delusional yahoos, that should convince everyone now.

Reportage photography has recently come under fire for being too subjective and bias. The argument is that the photographer is actively trying to sway the viewer toward his or her beliefs and prejudices. The problem with this argument is that it promotes a narrow minded approach to learning and formulating ones own interpretation of the issues, wholly. Keyword, wholly. Photography, especially reportage, happens fast and hard. You don't have much time to think, therefore the act of pressing the shutter becomes almost reflexive. There are definitely those that go into it with an agenda, but I'd say that even they get stripped of their preconceptions when the action fully envelops them. Perhaps it's this narrow minded approach that's holding back those who strive to break away from the conventional, sometimes antiquated photo-journalistic practices. Annalisa Natali Murri's piece is incredibly refreshing and enlightening because she does just that.
